formattedAddress: 44 W 63rd St., New York, NY 10023, USA
adrFormatAddress: 44 W 63rd St., New York, NY 10023, USA

editorialSummary.text: Burgers & other American comfort food in down-to-earth digs with a lively atmosphere.

originalText.text: Very nice restaurant, hyper friendly service, and a good menu. There are several raw dishes, including a nice variety of oysters. Price are normal for a NY restaurant (expensive, but no more than others). I enjoyed a really good meal here, with a Clarke's Burger. It's been a while since I tasted the pure meat and simple ingredients that made hamburgers famous. No bacon, cheese, caramelized onions. Just the basics. And the cheesecake ... A real New York one! It was a great experience, recommended.

originalText.text: 30min wait for a table which was not bad for a busy day. The space was a tad crowded. Our waitress was nice but everything took a very long time, taking the orders and bringing the food and drinks. The food is very good. My husband realized his glass was cracked all the way down and he Informed the waitress and normally at a good restaurant the entire drink would be exchanged, here the drink was transferred, so watered downed and maneuvered which was not expected of a good restaurant, expected better service and protocols for that scenario.

originalText.text: The place is pretty crowded even on a weekday during lunch time. The prices are on a higher end, friendly staff, and the place is very clean. I have ordered a burger for myself but I heard their burgers are delicious. I ordered for myself spicy shrimp with capellini, and it was delicious. However,  I wish there would be more shrimp in the dish.

text.text: The place is pretty crowded even on a weekday during lunch time. The prices are on a higher end, friendly staff, and the place is very clean. originalText.text:
Really a 2.5 but the atmosphere is cool enough so we'll round up.

Place is just "ok."

My service was fine. Food was less stellar. Like so many other reviews have mentioned, it not much for the price. Don't expect to get a sizable portion at all. I'm sure there is a "Lincoln Square" surcharge here because the prices just don't add up.

The chicken pot pie (pictured) is rather basic. Mine was hot and not just warm tho. It was smallish and taste wise, it was... Fine.

The scallops was ordered by someone else at the table and that was a little better but quiet underwhelming as far as amount and still just fine on the taste-o-meter.

Somebody else had the BBQ burger with fries. Fries weren't bad tho.

This IS NOT a place you come out the way to. You just might even consider passing this place up leaving out of a show at Lincoln Square to be honest. But if you came, you won't be impressed and probably not let down but there is a possibility you could be.

originalText.text:
I recently visited P.J. Clarke's at Lincoln Square, a restaurant steeped in history since its inception in 1884, originally catering to Irish immigrant laborers. Now expanded to three locations in NYC, as well as one each in Washington DC and Philadelphia, the place holds a special spot in the city's culinary map.

The ambiance at the Lincoln Square location certainly resonates with its great history, offering a delightful atmosphere. However, my dining experience did not live up to the expectations set by the restaurant's legacy. The food, while adequate, fell short in terms of design, quality, and portion size, especially considering the prices. It gave me the impression that the kitchen staff was more focused on quickly turning out orders rather than paying attention to the presentation and quality of the dishes.

Although P.J. Clarke's boasts a fantastic location and has a remarkable history, my overall experience was underwhelming. The culinary aspect, unfortunately, did not match the charm and legacy of its setting. For a place with such a rich past and promising ambiance, I had hoped for a dining experience that reflected the same standards.
